Content: When I started Starteryou, I had no funding, no knowledge, and I actually had to Google what nda stood for during my first mentor meeting.I had no idea how companies actually worked. But I was obsessed with building one.So I started doing the only thing I could: asking questions. Constantly.My strategy was to DM and email experienced strangers and say:“I’m working on a startup and need some honest advice. Could I setup a quick meeting?”Mentors didn’t just help me build the startup. They taught me how to make decisions, manage people, and lead. Not to mention, they became valuable additions to my network.Some of the best tools I’ve used, completely free: MicroMentor – 1:1 mentoring for entrepreneurs, founders, and career seekers around the world Score.org – free mentoring from business professionals with decades of experience PushFar – a powerful mentorship platform to connect with experienced professionals in your field YouTube – yes, if you follow the right people, it can become a personal MBAYou can even go to your school’s LinkedIn page, search for alumni by industry, and reach out to them directly, I’ve done it over 50 times myself.The truth is: You don’t need a crazy background to get guidance. You need curiosity, humility, and the willingness to ask.I’m still learning every day. But I wouldn’t be here without the people who replied to those early messages. So please take a moment to reach out and set up a meeting with someone in the industry you want to learn from. Just remember to be extremely appreciative of their time. Let me know if you need help.

Content: No company is visiting to hire Data Scientist/ML Engineer in my college.From July 15th, the placement season started and more than 15 companies had their Online Assessment but no company is hiring for Data Science roles and I did only Data Science courses.This is Day 2 of hashtaghashtag#CampusStories where we decode the stories from this Placement Season.Everyone is talking about AI/ML and how GenAI will change the landscape, its correct but why no companies are hiring for Data Science roles in my college. This is because :- Data Science roles are more of research and programming and companies prefer someone who has a research background probably someone with a Masters or a PhD in Data Science for these roles.- ⁠The demand for these roles is there but as experienced engineers and not freshers.- ⁠Doing only Data Science Courses would not get you a job, your CV requires real skills.- ⁠For these roles, companies won’t come to hire - you have to showcase your skillset in Kaggle competitions or Data Science Hackathons and you will get these roles.- ⁠Doing internships in smaller startups during college would be very helpful if you are clear that you are built for Data Science roles.But even if you are looking for such roles, the advice would be to strengthen your problem solving skills, learn fundamentals of computer science and this will open you various avenues. For e.g. You get hired in an MNC for a Software role but you can work there and switch internally to a Data Science role if you have skills.So its not about the role, but more about how well you are with the skillset and hunger - you will ace it.This was Day 2 , see you in Day 3 of hashtag#CampusStories where we decode Placement Season of this year :)

Content: Every day, 100,000 to 300,000 people on LinkedIn read my content. Every week, 1 Million+ (all organic) But it’s not luck, timing, or AI. It’s strategy.And here are 15 of my most effective tips:1. Only 1% of LinkedIn users post weekly.If you’re posting consistently, you’re already ahead of 99%.(Source: LinkedIn’s Creator Economy Report)2. Posts with a bold POV → 10x more saves.People don’t save “nice” content.They save content that challenges how they think.3. The best hooks don’t explain, they provoke.Weak: “5 lessons from my startup journey.”Strong: “We raised ₹1.2 Cr, spent it wrong, and I lost 2 friends.”4. Emotional engagement = better reach.Posts that trigger anger, surprise, or pride outperform neutral content by 45–60%.(Harvard Business Review)5. Story posts outperform educational ones in pure reach.But educational posts convert 3x better.Use stories to build visibility. Use value to build business.6. 80% of my best-performing posts end with a mic-drop line.Never trail off.End with punch or pause.Leave your reader thinking or reacting.7. Format = trust signal.The first 3 seconds = visual scan.Use whitespace, clear formatting, short sentences, and bold structure.People scroll faster than they read.8. 90% of creators post for likes.The top 1% post to drive action.Lead them to your DMs, newsletter, offer, landing page, or comment section.9. One idea per post. Always.You’re not writing a blog. You’re building one sharp, scroll-stopping conversation starter.10. If it’s not relatable, it’s forgettable.No one cares what you achieved if they don’t understand where you started.11. Share your process, not just your results.“From 0 to ₹5L/month” is cool.But showing how you did it? That’s where credibility lives.12. DMs = revenue.60% of my high-ticket consulting leads came from posts that actually add value and speak results.13. Reshare rate > Like count.If people are hitting “Repost,” your content is building community trust.That’s the metric most creators sleep on.14. Best time to post on LinkedIn: Morning hours, 8am–10am IST.That’s when decision-makers scroll, and engagement signals rise faster.15. Your personal brand = business moat.Offers can be copied. Skills can be matched.But your voice, your face, your ideas?That’s what makes people trust, buy, and stay.You don’t need viral reach.You need repeatable impact.I went from being a random LinkedIn creator to ranking among Top Personal Branding & Marketing Leaders Globally. Start creating on LinkedIn Build trust. Build positioning. Build presence.That’s how you go from being just a ‘creator’ to becoming the “category leader”. 👑LinkedIn Guide to Creating hashtag#PersonalBranding hashtag#CreatorEconomy hashtag#ContentCreation hashtag#Marketing hashtag#CareerGrowth

Content: Should you hire a friend or relative in your company? I’d NEVER do that. I say this as someone who learned it the hard way.There’s always this unsaid rule, “Give them a chance, they’re your own.”But here’s what no one tells you:Your company is not your family’s charity project.It’s your vision.Your risk.Your sleepless nights.Your blood, sweat, and balance sheet.And when you hire someone just because you know them; not because they deserve the seat, you compromise everything you’ve built.I once hired someone I trusted personally. Because I thought:“Let me help them.”“They’ll understand me better.”“It’ll be easy to work with someone I already trust.”I couldn’t have been more wrong.Here’s what actually happened:→ Expected special treatment.→ Took feedback personally.→ Missed deadlines without guilt.→ And assumed I owed them flexibility just because of our personal bond.The worst part?I couldn’t even call them out the way I’d call any other employees.Because, “Gharwale kya kahenge?”And family dinners got awkward real quick. You can’t fire a cousin easily.You can’t challenge a best friend without creating rifts.And you definitely can’t build a high-performance culture when one team member thinks they are special and the rules don’t apply to them.If you’re a first-generation entrepreneur like me, you already fight too many battles.Don’t make emotional baggage one of them.It’s hard, I know.Instead:→ Hire for skill.→ Train like they owe you results, not favors.→ And keep your inner circle sacred—but out of payroll.Hire people who earn the seat.Not people you’re emotionally obligated to give it to.Build a company where relationships are earned through performance, not birthright.That’s how you protect your dream.So here’s my rule now:Help friends outside the company.Build with professionals inside it.What’s your take?hashtag#founders hashtag#startups hashtag#entrepreneurship hashtag#relationships hashtag#workculture

Content: Welcome to LinkedIn 2025: The Algorithm has Changed!Now you could get a Million impressions, without even posting!Here’s the secret: comment.The algorithm is no longer rewarding creators for just showing up.It’s rewarding how you show up.And this month, everything changed again.➡️ The July 2025 LinkedIn Algorithm Update: 6 Game-Changing Shifts: 1. Comments > PostsYour comment under a viral post can now reach more people than the original post.→ Top creators are seeing 20k–100k+ impressions per comment→ Meaning: You don’t need to post daily, you need to engage smartly.Find high-authority accounts. Add insight, not flattery. (Btw, I generated 200K+ impressions just by commenting)2. The Feed Now Recycles Posts From 2–3 Weeks Ago→ LinkedIn’s pushing posts that still generate dwell time or profile clicks→ This extends the life cycle of content and increases ROI on quality postsPost less often, but more intentionally. Let your good posts work longer.3. “Follow First” is Replacing “Connect”New users are now set to follow creators by default → Your audience is expanding quietly, not loudly→ More visibility, less engagement, more silent influenceWrite for the silent 90%, people who never comment, but watch everything.4. “Value Per Viewer” Is the New CurrencyLinkedIn is no longer rewarding vanity metrics→ It tracks: dwell time, saves, profile clicks, and how your post fits viewer intent→ Posts that “sound viral” but feel hollow are tankingFocus on resonance > reach. Depth > dopamine.5. Comments Are Also Creating Creator Visibility Loops→ If someone engages with your comment, LinkedIn is more likely to show them your future posts→ This creates a “loop of interest” even without followersTreat your comment section like your first impression engine.6. Your Post’s Performance Now Influences Your Profile Discoverability→ Posts with saves, re-visits, or shares trigger profile visits→ And LinkedIn now nudges those same users to follow you more aggressivelyClean up your profile headline + About.The Real Game in 2025:It’s not just “posting daily.” It’s: •	Smart commenting •	Writing for lurkers •	Optimizing for longevity •	Earning trust over time, not attention overnightThis platform is changing and your playbook should too.♻️ Repost to help someone stop chasing likes and start building leverageLinkedIn for Marketing | LinkedIn Guide to Creating hashtag#linkedinalgorithm hashtag#LinkedInGrowth hashtag#LinkedInExpert

Content: I used to think being a “good leader” just meant being nice.Say thank you. Smile more. Don’t shout.How hard could it be?As an intern, I used to judge the people leading me.“He’s too rude.”“She’s so kind, must be a great boss.“That one? Cold, must be a bad manager.”But now…I’m on the other side and I realize it’s so tough becoming a good leader.Now that I run a team at Iconify Consulting Group (ICG), I understand how much discipline, emotional control, and silent weight sits behind that “kindness.”And how being a good leader doesn’t just require empathy, it demands discernment.- It’s about holding both at the same time: kindness and clarity, empathy and accountability.- It’s knowing when to stay silent and when to speak up.- It’s knowing when to give someone a second chance…And when that second chance is hurting the rest of your team.- It’s learning to pay people who haven’t performed well and still showing up the next day without letting resentment color your tone.- It’s letting someone go not because you’re angry, but because the role needs something they no longer want to give.Some days I’ve felt like the entire agency was resting on a thread of patience.Other days, I’ve wondered if I’ll ever learn how to lead without overgiving… or shutting down.No handbook prepares you for those 10-second moments where you have to decide:Do I ignore this? Do I address it now?Do I defend this person or hold the line?I haven’t cracked it yet. But every time I talk to the clients I look up to, leaders who’ve built teams of 500, 10000, 50,000 people: I realize something.Their calm isn’t performative.Their kindness isn’t passive.It’s all built. Earned. Practiced.They’ve taught me more than any book or business post ever could:→ That power isn’t loud.→ That leadership isn’t ego.→ That the real job is showing up, again and again, without losing yourself.If you’re a leader or manager, drop your best advice below 👇 PS: A little note of thanks to some of the best bosses I’ve met, who probably don’t even realize how much they’ve taught me.Vasantha | Glenn | Bimal | Babjee M | Lauren | Carlos | Monika | Kai | Nakul You don’t just lead teams. You build people.hashtag#leadership hashtag#leaders hashtag#culture

Title: Building Supersourcing & EngineerBabu
Content: 𝗧𝗵𝗲𝘆 𝘀𝗮𝘆: 𝗡𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿 𝗺𝗶𝘅 𝗳𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗹𝘆 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗯𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀. 𝗜 𝗱𝗶𝗱.𝗔𝗻𝗱 𝗶𝘁 𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗻𝗲𝗱 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝗯𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗺𝗮𝗿𝘁𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗿𝗶𝘀𝗸 𝗜 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿 𝘁𝗼𝗼𝗸."“Never hire your family.”That’s what they say, right?“Family in business ruins both.”“It’s messy, emotional, and never ends well.”Maybe they’re right—for 90% of people.But I’m here to talk about the 10%.𝗔𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆, 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 1 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 10%—𝗺𝘆 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹 𝘀𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗿.I was 200% sure I wanted her on the team.Not as a shortcut.Not as “Aditi’s sister.”But as a developer, starting from the ground up.I told her one thing before she joined:"If you want this, you'll have to earn it all. Every inch. Every title."And she did.- She didn’t ask for comfort.- She didn’t expect applause.- She just showed up—day after day, learning, building, failing, and rising again.- She took feedback with courage.- She stayed up nights to crack problems.And she never let her last name buy her an easy way out.Me and Mayank mentored her, but the fire? That was all hers.And that fire turned her into a leader.𝗧𝗼𝗱𝗮𝘆, 𝗜’𝗺 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗵𝗲𝗿 𝗰𝗼-𝗳𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿.𝗜’𝗺 𝗮 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝘂𝗱 𝘀𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗿.She now leads EngineerBabu as a Founding Partner,helping companies go digital and rewriting her own story one solution at a time.She didn’t inherit that title.She earned it. With sweat, late nights, and silent resilience.𝗧𝗼 𝗮𝗻𝘆𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝘄𝗵𝗼 𝘀𝗮𝘆𝘀 "𝗗𝗼𝗻’𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗳𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗹𝘆"—𝗜 𝗮𝗴𝗿𝗲𝗲. 𝗗𝗼𝗻’𝘁 𝗵𝗶𝗿𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗺 𝗮𝘀 𝗳𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗹𝘆.𝗛𝗶𝗿𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗺 𝗶𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝘆’𝗿𝗲 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘆 𝘁𝗼 𝗼𝘂𝘁𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘆𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗲𝗹𝘀𝗲 𝗶𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗿𝗼𝗼𝗺.That’s what she did.And that’s why EngineerBabu is just getting started—again.Aanchal Chaurasia

Name: Aditi Chaurasia
Title: Building Supersourcing & EngineerBabu
Content: 𝐄𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐲 𝐟𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫 𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐝𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐨𝐧𝐞 𝐛𝐞𝐥𝐢𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐫. Accept it or not. The one who sees your potential before you do.Mine was Mayank.When the world was busy judging me for being a female founder, from a small remote village. He wasn’t watching.He was backing me.Quietly. Fiercely. Without second-guessing.When I was uncertain about my career...struggling, doubting. Applying for jobs I didn’t want but felt needed to do.He looked at me and said,“𝑫𝒐𝒏’𝒕 𝒇𝒐𝒍𝒍𝒐𝒘 𝒕𝒉𝒆 𝒕𝒓𝒆𝒏𝒅. 𝑭𝒐𝒍𝒍𝒐𝒘 𝒚𝒐𝒖𝒓 𝒉𝒆𝒂𝒓𝒕.”That one sentence changed everything.I started my first venture—𝐓𝐢𝐭𝐥𝐢𝐲𝐚𝐧 𝐂𝐫𝐞𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬.Still unsure. Still figuring it out.But he was sure.He believed in me when I didn’t.When people thought I didn’t have what it takes.He saw everything I could become.Even when I had to shut Titliyan for personal reasons—He never once questioned my potential.Instead, he asked me to join him and build EngineerBabu together.Since then- He’s not just been my co-founder.He’s been my loudest supporter.📌 Every bold decision I made—he stood by it.📌 Every time I took the lead—he amplified it.📌 Every time I broke down—he held space for it.When everyone doubted me. He asked me to lead from the front as 𝑪𝑬𝑶.He never tried to “empower” me.𝐇𝐞 𝐬𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐲 𝐭𝐫𝐮𝐬𝐭𝐞𝐝 𝐦𝐞.𝐀𝐬 𝐚 𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐞𝐫. 𝐀𝐬 𝐚 𝐟𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫. 𝐀𝐬 𝐦𝐞.Because real belief doesn’t look like big gestures.It looks like "𝐓𝐫𝐮𝐬𝐭".Every day. In every room. Especially when no one’s watching.To every founder out there. Find your believer.And be someone else’s too. Because your one belief can changes someone's life. hashtag#founderslife hashtag#cofounders hashtag#startuplife hashtag#leadership

Content: They say: 𝗬𝗼𝘂’𝗿𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗮𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝘁𝗵𝗲 5 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝘀𝗽𝗲𝗻𝗱 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗺𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗲 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵.And I say: 𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆’𝘀 𝗴𝗿𝗼𝘄𝘁𝗵 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗮𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗺’𝘀 𝗰𝗮𝗽𝗮𝗯𝗶𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆.- Not your pitch.- Not your deck.- Not even your dream.𝗬𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝗱𝗲 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗳𝗮𝗿 𝘆𝗼𝘂’𝗹𝗹 𝗴𝗼.You can be the best founder in the room, but if the room isn’t growing it’s capability with you—you’ll get stuck.I’ve lived this.The years we grew the fastest weren’t the ones with the most revenue, but the ones where my team grew in mindset, ownership, and maturity. You can’t be smartest person in the room if you want to grow.Hunt smart people. 𝗧𝗵𝗲 𝗿𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁 𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗺 𝗱𝗼𝗲𝘀 𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝗻 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗲𝘅𝗲𝗰𝘂𝘁𝗲.- They see what you miss.- They take calls you’re not in.- They make your vision bigger than you imagined. - They multiply outcomes faster than you do aloneSo no, I don’t chase unicorn status.𝗜 𝗰𝗵𝗮𝘀𝗲 𝗮 𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗺 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘄𝘀 𝘂𝗽 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝘆 𝗼𝘄𝗻 𝗶𝘁..Because that’s when things really scale. And the company would eventually grow. 𝗪𝗵𝗲𝗻 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗺 𝗶𝘀𝗻’𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆—𝗧𝗵𝗲𝘆’𝗿𝗲 𝗯𝘂𝗶𝗹𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝘁 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝘆𝗼𝘂.

Name: Aditi Chaurasia
Title: Building Supersourcing & EngineerBabu
Content: Want people to stay?Don’t just pay them well,𝑮𝒓𝒐𝒘 𝒕𝒉𝒆𝒎 𝒘𝒆𝒍𝒍.We think we hired someone and our job is done.No.The real job starts now.Once you find the right talent, what matters most is creating the space where they can perform, grow, and feel safe enough to bring their best.Over the years at EngineerBabu and Supersourcing, I’ve seen this truth play out again and again- Hiring is not the hard part.Retaining and growing the right people is.Anyone can hire talent with a good JD and salary.But keeping them inspired, accountable, and evolving?That takes real effort.What matters to good talent today is a workplace that: 1. 𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐡𝐢𝐩 𝐧𝐨𝐭 𝐝𝐢𝐜𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐨𝐫𝐬𝐡𝐢𝐩, which inspire them into ownership. Fear brings compliance, not creativity.If your team is scared of making mistakes, they’ll stop taking initiative.They’ll wait for approvals. Delayed decisions. Slowly disconnect.We want thinkers, not task-doers.2. 𝐒𝐚𝐟𝐞𝐭𝐲 = 𝐑𝐞𝐭𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧. 𝐀𝐥𝐰𝐚𝐲𝐬.So ask yourself—Is your workplace a safe space?Not where everything is easy, but where they can say:“I don’t know.”“I failed.”“I need help.”And still feel valued. A space where people feel free to commit mistakes, speak up, and grow? Because talent doesn’t bloom under pressure.It blooms where it feels safe.3. 𝐁𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐩𝐞𝐨𝐩𝐥𝐞 𝐥𝐢𝐤𝐞 𝐲𝐨𝐮'𝐫𝐞 𝐛𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐚𝐧𝐲.If you expect someone to help you build your dream—You’ve got to help them build theirs too.Gone are the days when people stayed just because the job paid the bills.Today, they stay for growth. For respect. For mental peace.It’s not about perks anymore.It’s about being the best choice in a world full of options.Today’s talent doesn’t just look for a job—they choose a workplace that stands out.Make sure yours does.Because in the end—People don’t join and stay where they’re paid the most.They chose where they could grow the most.And if you want your company to grow,first—grow your people.hashtag#startuplife hashtag#leadership hashtag#success hashtag#team

Name: Aditi Chaurasia
Title: Building Supersourcing & EngineerBabu
Content: 𝗧𝗵𝗲𝘆 𝘀𝗮𝗶𝗱—'𝗧𝗶𝗲𝗿 2 𝗳𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗰𝗮𝗻’𝘁 𝘀𝘂𝗿𝘃𝗶𝘃𝗲.'We said—'Watch us build.'- We walked and cycled to the office.- We had pani puri instead of burgers.- We gave appraisals to our team—and returned our own salaries.- We were everything—from founders to peons.Supersourcing is now funded.But before that, 𝘄𝗲 𝗯𝗼𝗼𝘁𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗲𝗱 EngineerBabu 𝗳𝗼𝗿 7 𝗹𝗼𝗻𝗴 𝘆𝗲𝗮𝗿𝘀.And let me tell you—that was the hardest time ever.Back then, bootstrapping wasn’t even considered respectful.No investors meant—“𝗳𝗼𝘂𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗺𝗲 𝗱𝘂𝗺 𝗻𝗮𝗵𝗶 𝗵𝗮𝗶.”No funding = no credibility.You had to prove your worth twice as hard, every single day.But what’s bootstrapping look like from inside:— Not taking salary for months— We survived on bare minimum ₹4,000/month for 2 years— Hiring interns and training them like co-founders— Getting rejected by clients and talent because you didn’t have an office— Being judged for being tier-2 founders, as if ambition has a pin code— Hearing “You won’t survive,” “You won’t scale,” “You won’t raise”— Waking up every day wondering how long you can sustain— Choosing business needs over your own personal comfortsAnd still…showing up.Every single day. Because you are the founder. We said no to short-term hacks, yes to slow compounding.We learned to sell, build, manage, pitch, lead — all at once.And you know what?That struggle-built muscle is the reason we stood strong—during COVID, during the funding winter, and every other storm that came our way.Bootstrapping is not just a funding choice.- It’s a mindset.- It teaches you how to stretch ₹1 like ₹100.- It makes your team emotionally invested.- It shows you the difference between survival and scale.𝗦𝗼 𝗶𝗳 𝘆𝗼𝘂'𝗿𝗲 𝗯𝗼𝗼𝘁𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗿𝗶𝗴𝗵𝘁 𝗻𝗼𝘄 — 𝗥𝗲𝘀𝗽𝗲𝗰𝘁. 𝗧𝗿𝘂𝗹𝘆.You're doing the hardest and most beautiful kind of entrepreneurship.And when it pays off, it’s 100% yours.

Name: Aditi Chaurasia
Title: Building Supersourcing & EngineerBabu
Content: 𝗖𝘂𝗹𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗱.𝗣𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝗳𝘂𝘀𝗲 𝗶𝘁 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗸𝘀.Quarterly offsites.Free snacks, nap pods, ping pong tables.Fun Fridays. Cake Cuttings.Motivational speeches.We don’t do these at SupersourcingBecause startup culture isn’t about optics.It’s about ownership, trust, and belonging.When you go to a temple, you don’t wait for someone to tell you to bow.You just do.Out of respect. Out of belief. Out of connection.𝗧𝗵𝗮𝘁’𝘀 𝗰𝘂𝗹𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲.At Supersourcing, we’re building that same instinct.- A place where people don’t need permission to be themselves.- Where leaders are mentors, not just during 1:1s, but in every challenge,    breakdown, and decision. - With us or not, if someone has been part of our journey,we remain their mentors for life.- Where work and life co-exists. Because we believe in our people.And they believe in us.And that’s the only kind of culture I ever wanted to create.𝗛𝗲𝗿𝗲’𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗶𝘁 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗹𝗼𝗼𝗸𝘀 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝗮𝘁 𝗦𝘂𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗰𝗶𝗻𝗴:✅ Ownership levels that feel unreal✅ People can say “I don’t know,” “I made a mistake,” or “I disagree” — without fear✅ 1:1s that aren’t feedback sessions — they’re safe spaces for mentoring✅ Continuous feedback — not saved up for “review days”✅ We hustle together: company grows → people grow✅ Most of our leads started as interns, we promote from within✅ Strict log-off hours, because hustle ≠ burnout✅ We train like mentors, not like a T&D department✅ We ask: “What would you do if you were the founder?”We’ve navigated the toughest of times with our culture,because it made sure we had each other’s back.We stood by our people in their hardest moments.And they stood by Supersourcing in ours.I still remember when Raju Bhaiya needed home, how each team member contributed, and how he returned money even when few of them left the organisation. That’s what is real culture. Inbuilt, engrossed.

Name: Aditi Chaurasia
Title: Building Supersourcing & EngineerBabu
Content: We almost didn’t make these 2 decisions.But thank god we did, because Supersourcing wouldn’t be what it is today without them :📍From services → productBack then, we were operating as EngineerBabu, and we saw a pattern.Clients weren’t just asking us to code apps; they were relying on us to build entire engineering teams, from hiring devs to setting up interview processes and retention systems.We realised this wasn’t just a one-off service.It was a repeatable engine.So I told the team, if we’re doing this more than twice,Let’s build a product around it.Let’s automate the repetitive, standardise the process, and give it a name that matches the value.That’s how Supersourcing was born.“Supersourcing” was clear, direct, and easy to understand.It repositioned us overnight.Same vision with sharper focus and faster growth.📍Choosing customers over vanity metricsTwo years ago, we hit every founder’s nightmare - a funding winter.And we realised, the only money that actually comes in… is from the customer.So we made a choice to put customers first.It changed:→ Our hiring→ Our roadmap→ Our KPIs→ How we define successAnd because of this, today we work with amazing enterprise clients who see us as their trusted hiring partner.Retention improved. Revenue per client increased.These two decisions - a clear positioning + a customer-first mindset: → made the company profitable → and made the culture focused.Was it scary? Absolutely. Irreversible? Yes. Will I change it? Not a single thing.(P.S. always grateful to our awesome investor friends who let us follow the customer, not the crowd )

Content: Scrolling between office hours?Then you might be exactly who I’m looking for at Supersourcing.We’re HIRING amazing Marketing Interns and Freshers at SupersourcingBefore you send in resumes and decks, here’s a quick challenge:1. Title: Building Supersourcing & EngineerBabu
Content: It took me 4 years to crack THIS puzzle.Initially, I thought I could create a sustainable company just by hiring smart people and setting goals.Wrong.Smart people without systems = chaos. Systems without the right people = failure.After months of chaos, I realised every system only needs three things to work:📌 People (the right leaders): 3-4 years ago, I identified 4 people from our team who could potentially lead. Not because they were the best at their current jobs, but because they showed leadership potential.Out of those 4:> Kartik now leads Supersourcing as Co-Founder> Aanchal leads EngineerBabuThe power of identifying the right people early? Priceless.📌 Process (how decisions get made): We listed 50+ processes that needed to be defined. Then prioritized them:> Priority 1: 5 critical processes> Priority 2: 10 important ones> Priority 3: 20 supporting processesWe tackled one at a time. Built SOPs. Tested them. Broke them. Fixed them.📌 Strategy (the roadmap they follow)We adopted OKRs + Annual Operating Plans.> Break down yearly goals into quarters> Track weekly metrics> Course-correct immediately when numbers dipAfter 3–4 years of building, I finally stepped away (fully) during my first month postpartum.No panic. No fire-fighting.Yes, it takes time to build something that runs without you.Not 1 month. Not even 1 year.But give it 3–4 years…You’ll feel it when it clicks.

Name: Aditi Chaurasia
Title: Building Supersourcing & EngineerBabu
Content: A founder-controlled company might survive, but it won’t scale.For the longest time, I thought I had to know everything.Every problem. Every solution. Every decision.And the irony? The more I controlled, the more I slowed everything down.Even when the team had ideas, they waited. Because “Aditi will decide.”But you don’t build million-dollar companies like that :)So I changed.I sat down with the team and built a simple framework for delegation:→ If I know something for sure, I decide quickly.→ If I have a POV, I guide but don’t block.→ If we’re unclear, we solve it as a team.→ If it’s not mine, I step back and let them lead. Even if they make mistakes. Even if it doesn’t go perfectly the first time.Because that’s how leaders grow: By making the call. By owning the mistake. By fixing it the next time.I always tell founders:You cannot scale if you’re not willing to multiply your power.And that only happens when you do these 3 things:1) Hire right (someone with the X factor)2) Trust deeply even when it’s hard3) Ensure their growthIf you do these three things consistently, the rest follows.The performance, the ownership, the results - it all compounds.But it starts with one hard decision:Stop doing everything yourself.Start building people who can do it better than you ever could.

Name: Arvind Krishna
Title: Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, IBM
Content: Following IBM’s earnings announcement earlier today, I had a lot of conversation and without fail, DeepSeek came up. It’s clear this moment is resonating across the industry, so I wanted to share a few thoughts directly here.For too long, the AI race has been a game of scale where bigger models meant better outcomes. But there is no law of physics that dictates AI models must remain big and expensive. The cost of training and inference is just another technology challenge to be solved. We’ve seen this play out before. In the early days of computing, storage and processing power were prohibitively expensive. Yet, through technological advancements and economies of scale, these costs plummeted. AI will follow the same path.At IBM, we’ve been on this journey for years. We’ve been steadfast in our belief that efficient, fit-for-purpose models can deliver exceptional value and that open is key to innovation. Our work has already led to up to 30-fold reductions in inference costs.This is promising for businesses. Technology becomes truly transformative when it becomes more affordable. As more companies embrace this shift, we’ll see an AI landscape that is both more powerful and accessible.

Content: To the Sceptics - Digitization is Reshaping Agri Inputs Retail – What’s Next?The traditional agri-inputs distribution model which was largely dependent on physical retailers and dealer networks is rapidly evolving. Digitization is fueling an unprecedented shift, unlocking new efficiencies and improving farmer access to quality inputs. Here’s what’s challenging the status quo:🚜 Agri E-commerce Scaling Up Platforms like hashtag#AgroStar, hashtag#BigHaat, and hashtag#DeHaat are transforming how farmers buy inputs. By empowering the intermediaries, these marketplaces improve affordability, transparency, and doorstep delivery of seeds, fertilizers, and crop protection products.💡 IOT and ML based Advisory for Smarter Input Use - Precision agriculture tools powered by ML, remote sensing, and IoT are tailoring input recommendations based on soil health and weather data—leading to smarter, cost-effective decision-making. Companies like hashtag#Fasal and hashtag#Cropin are driving this change.📈 Embedded Financing for Agri Inputs Innovative models like pay-as-you-grow financing are reducing upfront costs for farmers. Digital credit platforms backed by NBFCs and fintech firms are helping farmers access high-quality inputs without financial strain.💬 Digitally Connected Agri-Retail Networks  - Agri input players are integrating digital touchpoints into traditional dealer and retail networks. WhatsApp-based ordering, e-Kisan Kendras, and rural digital advisory hubs are bridging the gap between online efficiencies and offline engagement.The future of agri-input retail is farmer-centric, tech-driven, and sustainability-focused. Companies not acknowledging and embracing these shifts risk not only opportunity of improving business outcomes but also  of  transforming agriculture at scale.🔍 What do you think?
